data.title: Israel Shares Full List of Palestinians To Be Released in Hostage Deal
data.meta_description: The names of Palestinian detainees who could be released as part of the deal to free Israeli hostages held by Hamas have been revealed.
data.text:
Israel's government has published a list of 300 Palestinian detainees who could be freed as part of a prisoner exchange with Hamas, following the announcement of a four-day ceasefire in Gaza.

The truce will allow aid into the territory and would see Israeli air sorties over southern Gaza cease amid a daily six-hour daytime no-fly window in the north.

Hamas will also release at least 50 of the 240 hostages it took on October 7 during its attacks on southern Israel, in which 1,200 people were killed according to the Associated Press.

Since then, more than 11,000 Palestinians have been killed in Israel's bombardment of Gaza, according to AP citing health officials in Hamas-controlled territory.

Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu's office said on Monday the hostages Hamas took would be released at a rate of at least 10 a day over four days and the truce could be extended if an additional ten hostages were freed daily.

The statement did not mention the fate of prisoners detained by Israel. However, Hamas said that the agreement will include the return of at least 150 Palestinians in Israel, Reuters reported. Israel could release another 150 pending another 50 hostages from Gaza being returned.

On Wednesday Israel's Justice Ministry published on its website a list of 300 Palestinian prisoners "slated for release," according to a translation. This publication is to give members of the public a chance to appeal against the release of specific prisoners, The Times of Israel reported.

The paper noted that the vast majority of the prisoners scheduled for possible release—287— are males aged 18 and under, detained for rioting and rock-throwing in the West Bank or East Jerusalem. The other 13 prisoners are adult women, who were mostly convicted of attempted stabbings.

Here is a machine translation from the Hebrew of the Israeli Justice Ministry's prisoner list, next to their ages.
